article.title: The Role of Estrogen Receptor α in Response to Longitudinal Bone Growth in ob/ob Mice

funding.text: National Natural Science Foundation of China
funding.normalized: national natural science foundation of china

funding.text: Procurement of Government of National Health Commission of China
funding.normalized: procurement of government of national health commission of china

article.abstract: The absence of leptin results in contrasting growth pattern of appendicular and axial bone growth in ob/ob mice. Endochondral bone formation is an important procedure of growth plate determining the bone growth, where this procedure is also regulated by estrogen and its receptor (ER) signaling pathway.

sections.introduction: Leptin, a protein encoded by obese gene (ob), has been shown to have regulative effects on longitudinal bone growth, spongiosa maturation, and bone turnover between cortical and cancellous bones (1).
sections.methods: Three-week-old female B6/JGpt-Lepem1Cd25/Gpt mice on the C57BL/6 background (ob/ob mice, n = 6/group) and 3-week-old female C57BL/6 (n = 6/group) mice were purchased from Nanjing GemPharmatech Co., Ltd.
sections.results: At the end of mice’s puberty, X-ray was performed to collect images of the femur and lumbar spine.
sections.discussion: Although the contrasting phenotypes in bone of the limb and spine were observed in leptin deficiency mice, the reason and mechanisms remain unclear and need to be explored.

experimental_factors.treatment: methyl-piperidino-pyrazole, an erα-selective antagonist (ob/ob + mpp), ob/ob mice were treated with 4-(2-phenyl-5, 7-bis(trifluoromethyl)pyrazolo(1, 5-a)pyrimidin-3-yl)phenol, an erβ-selective antagonist (ob/ob + phtpp)
experimental_factors.treatment_raw: methyl-piperidino-pyrazole, an ERα-selective antagonist (ob/ob + MPP), and ob/ob mice were treated with 4-(2-phenyl-5,7-bis(trifluoromethyl)pyrazolo(1,5-a)pyrimidin-3-yl)phenol, an ERβ-selective antagonist (ob/ob + PHTPP)

article.insights_summary: The absence of leptin results in contrasting growth pattern of appendicular and axial bone growth in ob/ob mice. Endochondral bone formation is an important procedure of growth plate determining the bone growth, where this procedure is also regulated by estrogen and its receptor (ER) signaling pathway.
